title: Lets poll the typography heads!
content:
So I was sitting around the other day and realized that I had some nice development on some type to help express my political views and had unfortunately done nothing with it. So I sat down for an hour and pushed something out for fun. I figured I would post it and see if we can get a poll on election day of the typography crowd up here. So throw them up! Take a few minutes (or more if able) and show your support for your party with a fancy little type lock up. You know, if you are into that kind of thing.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208191551im_/http:/typophile.com/files/obama-we-believe_3767.gif)

As a “foreigner” like Sii, I don’t get to vote in the U.S presidential election(s). This one has recieved so much attention outside the U.S that people over here and elsewhere have been saying we non-U.S citizens of the free Western world should get to vote for the U.S president since it affects us in more ways than we care to mention.

I like Barak Obama and think he would make an excellent president in 15 to 25 years from now, when he has more life experience and experience holding executive office. I know, he is an early bloomer, and America really needs change right now, but installing a young president who isn’t white-skinned is not the way to do it. Obama’s skin color is not an issue with me. His lack of experience and world weariness is tho. And not being white-skinned makes him the target of hatred and bigotry. I don’t want to see him get blown away. Watching Kennedy die was bad enuff. A liberal white-skinned nominee devoted to change and pulling America out of Iraq, Afganistan and Pakistan, funding the war veterens hospitals and public health care system properly would be a better choice.

A large number of the public are still using the outmoded term “race” when referring to Obama. There is no such thing as race or races within the human species. We are all of the same race—homo sapiens. In a politically-correct liberal society, “race” should not be an issue to the extent it does not even rate a mention, yet people continue referring to Barak Obama’s “race”. So we ain’t there yet.

j a m e s

America has had years of presidents who were “experienced white guys” and look what a mess we are in. I could care less what race or sex our presidents are. I just don’t want any more invaders of foreign countries who are beholding to big oil and big defense companies destroying our country. I prefer to let a younger person with a brain have a chance to start us back in the direction of peace and prosperity.

I agree with most of what you’re saying Chris, except I’m not recommending just any old “experienced white guy”. A liberal white-skinned guy, or even a white-skined woman.

The point about skin color is that Obama’s poses serious obstacles to his potential effectiveness as commander in chief and obstacles to America moving forward. U.S citizens threw away their best candidate, Hillary Clinton. Hillary was well qualified for the job. British author Doris Lessing expressed much the same view I am expressing.

Experienced white guys are not the problem. America’s privately funded republic government is the problem. That and economic dependence on her munitions and war industry. America’s economy runs down when it doesn’t have a war to fight. As Gore Vidal said, “Why be a senator when you can just buy one?”

Giving a younger person with a brain a chance at leading the country is a nice idea, but how practical is it?

And once again you are perpetuating the term “race”. There is no such thing. Obama is the same species as you and I.

Get real. America is a crumbling empire, like many before. Many ugly things happen during this process, just read your history. When you spread yourself too thin the Huns attack you from the North, the Celts revolt in the Northwest, etc…

There aren’t solutions for this, it is inevitable. The question is what will we do on the way down and how many will we take with us?

\>Giving a younger person with a brain a chance at leading the country is a nice idea, but how practical is it?

Obama ran an astoundingly disciplined campaign. He came from basically out of nowhere and managed to unseat the frontrunner in the primary, Hillary. He had an organized field operation that turned out the vote in places that had not voted for a democrat in decades. His first real act as candidate was choosing a vice president; he went with a man who has the experience he lacks rather than a publicity grab like Sarah Palin. He has shown extraordinary judgment and restraint in the general election. I have no doubt that Obama will staff his administration with smart, experienced advisors. I trust that he will have learned from what went on the past 8 years and cooperate with the other side, especially since he’s facing the sorts of challenges (economy, wars, healthcare, global warming) that require a bipartisan effort rather than just ramming legislation through.

And importantly, he represents a chance for America to redeem its tattered reputation abroad.

youth and race have nothing to do with qualifications. he will surround himself with experts and advisors of all ages and races.

Well, I’m sitting up here in Canada, right on top of good ol christian america. I doubt most americans realize their neighbours to the north also just finished a federal election.

Yup, that’s right, we re-elected Stephen Harper as Prime-Minister of Canada.

Now, what do I think of the election, living almost within sight of the US, and raised in a half-american home?

If this election shows us one thing, it’s that the mainstream american media has more power than ever. Most americans I talked to for the longest time though the election was between Hilary and Obama.

As america’s #1 trading partner, Obama gives me the heebie-jeebies. He focuses on America’s weaknesses and mistakes, and his promise of change, but I haven’t heard enough of his political platform, his plans and his personal worldview to support the man.

McCain does talk, and I believe him to be a liar, or delusional.

We all know Obama was going to get in, and we’re in for a 4 year ride. Please, please all americans get involved in politics in your community, get involved and don’t let your country go to waste because of a leader (no matter who it is)

I think the next election will be the one that uses the Internet in place of Television as the deciding battleground - it would be wise to start working on that framework and technology now!
